reviewText: Just after World War II, Ignat, a Soviet war hero, arrives at a Gulag camp in a remote section of Siberia, in order to try to handle a steam locomotive that is there. Soon he takes as his lover one of the prisoners, the pretty Sofia. Eventually, Ignat is told another locomotive is in an uninhabited forbidden island in a lake near the camp. When he goes to recover the locomotive, he finds a wild girl is living there, a German named Elsa who has been hiding there since the war started and the Russians killed her family (she is played by the pretty German actress Anjorka Strechel; unfortunately, it's hard to see her beauty in the movie since most of the time she is covered in dirt and dressed with shabby clothes). Ignat brings Elsa back to the camp in the broken locomotive, and soon sparks will fly between Elsa and Sofia for the love of Ignat. Since I love trains and snowy forests, I really liked this movie, though is a bit hampered by some very arbitrary plot points and a weak script. Also, I wondered if the portrayal of the Gulag camp is realistic, since it is not shown here to be such a terrible place (when, in fact, hundreds of thousands of people if not millions die in the Gulag camps for otherwise treatable illnesses, malnutrition, exposure to the elements, etc.). The movie is very muscular (for lack of a better word), with the male characters hitting each other hard at the faintest of motives. The female characters also fight each other: the movie most memorable scene, is a nude cat fight between Elsa and Sofia, with all the other naked woman in the camp watching. Recommended.
summary: Unusual Russian movie, entertaining, train buffs will like it especially

reviewText: Shortly after the end  of WW2, in the Siberian hinterland, Russians and Germans still  emphasize their differences with the damaged soul of both sides, defeated, humiliated and offended. On one hand the victors detest with thoughtless actions everything which is related or smells to German scent. Ignat embodies the larger- than-life image of the Soviet victorious, sick, disillusioned and seriously wounded spirit proves to be the first warrior of the road challenging all the possible obstacles. Trains become fetish for the warriors of the movie where the speed is a mania, they virtually blend themselves with the horses of iron that even take human names.Solid, courageous, vibrant and electrifying script with unstoppable adrenaline and realistic punch.This film was nominated for the Golden Globe as Best Foreign Film and I think to myself that was totally neglected for the Academy Awards.

reviewText: Sometime we are fascinated with some novels or films while we are not perfectly sure what they are all about. Some words or images stay with us even though we are unable to explain why. Aleksey Uchitel's Golden Globe-nominated film "The Edge" is one of such films, where following a story is virtually pointless. But anyway, I give it a try.Vladimir Mashkov (a Russian agent tracking down Ethan Hunt in "Mission: Impossible: Ghost Protocol") plays Ignat, a shell-shocked railway engineer working at a camp for "Nazi collaborators" in 1945 Siberia. Ignat is a tough and rough kind of person, who settles arguments with a punch.One day Ignat learns there is an abandoned steam engine in the nearby island, where a mysterious German girl named Elsa (Anjorka Strechel) lives alone. After the initial confrontation, Ignat and Elsa start working together, repairing the broken bridge to the island so that the locomotive can run again.Those who are looking for something like a 1985 action "Runaway Train" (a great film you should not miss) may be disappointed with "The Edge." There are powerful train chase sequences (twice!) and some dangerous stunts, but the scenes are obviously meant as a metaphor or representation of, say, clashing of power. You should see it for yourself.Also, unlike "The Way Back" (2010), this is not about a gulag and its prisoners who attempt to escape (there is no guard at the labor camp). Ignat repairs the steam engine not because he wants to run away (he can whenever he wants to), but because he wants that. The film is, to me, about a small community in the Siberian hinterland and ever-changing power dynamics among the people that change with the appearances of Ignat, a German girl (as unwelcome outsider who, ironically, did not know there was a war), and then "Fishman," about whom we know very little about.But of course this is my interpretation, and I don't pretend that I understand every aspect of this Russian film, which I believe is an interesting and baffling experience to every moviegoer.
summary: A Man, Two Women and Train Chases: Russian Fable That Is Intriguing and Elusive
